title: Bank of China participates in a USD $1.5 billion syndicated loan to San Miguel Corporation in June 2013
description: On June 3rd, 2013, San Miguel Corp signed a USD $1.5 billion syndicated loan contract with thirty-three banks, including Bank of China. Bank of China's Singapore, Grand Cayman, and Manila branches collectively contributed $56 million USD to the loan syndicate as a mandated lead arranger.   Mandated lead arrangers and bookrunners Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Maybank’s international and Philippines arms, Mizuho Corporate Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp took $102.5m each. The other MLABs — Australia and New Zealand Bank, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, DBS, Standard Chartered and United Overseas Bank — received allocations of $78m. Among the MLAs, Rabobank was given $80m and ING $58m. Bank of China took a total of $56m, split between its Singapore, Grand Cayman and Manila branches. Chinatrust Commercial Bank — the Hong Kong and the Philippines branches — received a combined $56m, while HSBC and its Philippines branch took $50m. Lead arranger Export Development Canada got $50m, and First Gulf Bank got $44m. The remaining amount was divided among the 17 arrangers: Taiwan Cooperative Bank got $40m, Mega International Commercial Bank $36m, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank $27m and State Bank of India $22m, while Bank of East Asia, Bank of Taiwan, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, Taichung Commercial Bank and Taiwan Business Bank each took $18m. KEB Asia Finance received $9m, while Korea Exchange Bank (Hong Kong) took $4m. Yuanta Commercial Bank came in with $12m, and $10m each went to Bank of Kaohsiung, Cathay Bank and E.Sun Commercial Bank.  This loan carried an interest rate of USD LIBOR plus a margin of 235 bps. The loan was oversubscribed from its $1.3 billion USD target. The proceeds were to be used to repay a $1bn five year loan taken in 2012, with the remainder to be used for general corporate purposes.
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title
Bank of China participates in a USD $1.5 billion syndicated loan to San Miguel Corporation in June 2013

# Description
On June 3rd, 2013, San Miguel Corp signed a USD $1.5 billion syndicated loan contract with thirty-three banks, including Bank of China. Bank of China's Singapore, Grand Cayman, and Manila branches collectively contributed $56 million USD to the loan syndicate as a mandated lead arranger.   Mandated lead arrangers and bookrunners Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Maybank’s international and Philippines arms, Mizuho Corporate Bank and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp took $102.5m each. The other MLABs — Australia and New Zealand Bank, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, DBS, Standard Chartered and United Overseas Bank — received allocations of $78m. Among the MLAs, Rabobank was given $80m and ING $58m. Bank of China took a total of $56m, split between its Singapore, Grand Cayman and Manila branches. Chinatrust Commercial Bank — the Hong Kong and the Philippines branches — received a combined $56m, while HSBC and its Philippines branch took $50m. Lead arranger Export Development Canada got $50m, and First Gulf Bank got $44m. The remaining amount was divided among the 17 arrangers: Taiwan Cooperative Bank got $40m, Mega International Commercial Bank $36m, Chang Hwa Commercial Bank $27m and State Bank of India $22m, while Bank of East Asia, Bank of Taiwan, First Commercial Bank, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, Taichung Commercial Bank and Taiwan Business Bank each took $18m. KEB Asia Finance received $9m, while Korea Exchange Bank (Hong Kong) took $4m. Yuanta Commercial Bank came in with $12m, and $10m each went to Bank of Kaohsiung, Cathay Bank and E.Sun Commercial Bank.  This loan carried an interest rate of USD LIBOR plus a margin of 235 bps. The loan was oversubscribed from its $1.3 billion USD target. The proceeds were to be used to repay a $1bn five year loan taken in 2012, with the remainder to be used for general corporate purposes.
justification: The project involves participation in a syndicated loan for general corporate purposes, with no specific environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Syndicated loan for corporate purposes, no specific project details provided

title: Hanban funds establishment of Confucius Institute at the University of Bucharest
description: On May 30, 2012, Vice President of the China University of Political Science and Law (Chinese: 中国政法大学), led a delegation to visit Romania. During the visit, the delegation met with the President of the University of Bucharest (Romanian: Universitatea din București). The two sides exchanged views and signed a cooperation framework agreement.   Then, on March 19, 2013, a Confucius Institute was established officially at the University of Bucharest in partnership with the China University of Political Science and Law. On November 22, 2013, the Confucius Institute at the University of Bucharest was inaugurated.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban funds establishment of Confucius Institute at the University of Bucharest

# Description
On May 30, 2012, Vice President of the China University of Political Science and Law (Chinese: 中国政法大学), led a delegation to visit Romania. During the visit, the delegation met with the President of the University of Bucharest (Romanian: Universitatea din București). The two sides exchanged views and signed a cooperation framework agreement.   Then, on March 19, 2013, a Confucius Institute was established officially at the University of Bucharest in partnership with the China University of Political Science and Law. On November 22, 2013, the Confucius Institute at the University of Bucharest was inaugurated.
justification: Project focuses on educational and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for educational and cultural purposes

title: Chinese companies sponsor Chinese Dream Awards in Romania (Linked to Project ID#85308)
description: In June 2013, a group of Chinese companies created the Chinese Dream awards to support students and teachers of Chinese language and culture.  The financial value is unclear.  This project has reoccurred annually and is ongoing.  Three 1st prizes, five 2nd prizes and seven 3rd prizes for students, as well as five prizes for Special Merit in Teaching Chinese Language, five prizes for Major Contributions in Promoting Chinese Language and Culture, were awarded in 2013. The 2013 and 2014 awards together provided scholarships to 31 students and 19 teachers. In 2015, 15 students and 10 teachers received the awards. It is known that state-owned companies including China Shipping, ZTE, China Tobacco, and RCO supported this program.
staff_comments: Intent marked as mixed because it promotes education and culture.  Though the 2015 awards were delivered in the Chinese embassy, it does not appear that the Chinese government played any role in this project. This project involves only state-owned donors while the linked project #85308 includes private donor.

title: China Development Bank provides EUR 50 million loan to Green Vision Seven SRL for 82MW Solar Power Park Project (Linked to Project ID#73251)
description: In 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Green Vision Seven SRL — a special purpose vehicle (SPV) project company that is indirectly controlled by Hareon Solar Technology — signed an EUR 83 million loan agreement for an 82MW Solar Power Park Project. The loan was provided in a two tranches: an EUR 50 Million tranche (captured in Project ID#66498) and an EUR 38 million tranche (captured in Project ID#73251).   The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. This project, which cost EUR 100 million in total, involved an expansion in the power generation capacity of an existing photovoltaic park in the village of Ucea de Sus within Brașov County from 55 MW to 82MW. Construction began in April 2013 and ended in December 2013. Then, in 2014, the expanded photovoltaic park was put into operation. The park was later sold to a Chinese company called Jiangsu Sunshine Group.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Green Vision-Brasov Solar PV Park - 1A Project. Green Vision Seven SRL is a project company that is 95.5% owned by Hareon Solar Technology through a legal vehicle controlled by a subsidiary, Hareon Alps Holding, which is registered in Switzerland.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Development Bank provides EUR 50 million loan to Green Vision Seven SRL for 82MW Solar Power Park Project (Linked to Project ID#73251)

# Description
In 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Green Vision Seven SRL — a special purpose vehicle (SPV) project company that is indirectly controlled by Hareon Solar Technology — signed an EUR 83 million loan agreement for an 82MW Solar Power Park Project. The loan was provided in a two tranches: an EUR 50 Million tranche (captured in Project ID#66498) and an EUR 38 million tranche (captured in Project ID#73251).   The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. This project, which cost EUR 100 million in total, involved an expansion in the power generation capacity of an existing photovoltaic park in the village of Ucea de Sus within Brașov County from 55 MW to 82MW. Construction began in April 2013 and ended in December 2013. Then, in 2014, the expanded photovoltaic park was put into operation. The park was later sold to a Chinese company called Jiangsu Sunshine Group.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation through expansion of photovoltaic park capacity
evidence: 82MW Solar Power Park Project, expansion of photovoltaic park capacity, renewable energy focus

title: Chinese Banks Provide 427 Million RMB for Lightway Solar Romanian Photovoltaic Plant Investment (Linked to Project #66683)
description: In 2013, Lightway Solar, a Chinese manufacturer of photovoltaic products, plans to invest 610 Million RMB into a series of photovoltaic plants with a capacity of 50MW in Prundu, Giurgiu County, Romania. The company has secured approval from China’s Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) for the project development. NDRC, in its statement, said that 30% of the investment (183 Million RMB) would be provided by the company, while the remaining (427 Million RMB) should be gained through credit facilities from banks. The 183 Million RMB from Lightway Solar is coded in Project #66683 and the 427 Million RMB from Chinese banks has been coded in Project #73198.
staff_comments: As it is unclear which banks will provide the 427m RMB, and whether they will be private or state-owned, the flow class for this project has been coded as Vague (Commercial)
combined_text:

title: CDB provide $2 billion oil-backed loan to Rosneft for development of Vankor field in Krasnoyarsk and gas supply to China
description: On March 22, 2013, PJSC Rosneft Oil Company (‘Rosneft’) — a Russian state-owned oil company — and China Development Bank (CDB) signed a framework facilities agreement. Then, on June 21, 2013, Rosneft announced that it had signed a $2 billion facility (loan) agreement with CDB. The facility agreement was signed by Rosneft President and Chairman of the Management Board Igor Sechin and President of China Development Bank Zheng Zhijie as part of the visit of Xi Jinping, President of the People's Republic of China, to Russia. The loan carries a 16 year maturity (and a final maturity date of May 2029) and an unknown interest rate. It was secured (collateralized) with a contract for crude oil supplies signed by Rosneft and CNPC in 2009. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower for the development of Vankor field (an oil and gas field in Turukhansk District and Krasnoyarsk Krai within Eastern Siberia) and to facilitate the supply of gas to China. OJSC VTB Bank was the agent and passport bank for the loan.   On July 29, 2013, Rosneft disclosed that the $2 billion loan from CDB had fully disbursed in June 2013.
staff_comments: 1. Official source confirmation of the framework facilities agreement agreement can be accessed via https://www.rosneft.com/press/news/item/114908/2. Evidence of loan disbursement can be accessed via https://www.rosneft.com/upload/site2/document_cons_report/SyxruWR7K0.pdf
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
CDB provide $2 billion oil-backed loan to Rosneft for development of Vankor field in Krasnoyarsk and gas supply to China

# Description
On March 22, 2013, PJSC Rosneft Oil Company (‘Rosneft’) — a Russian state-owned oil company — and China Development Bank (CDB) signed a framework facilities agreement. Then, on June 21, 2013, Rosneft announced that it had signed a $2 billion facility (loan) agreement with CDB. The facility agreement was signed by Rosneft President and Chairman of the Management Board Igor Sechin and President of China Development Bank Zheng Zhijie as part of the visit of Xi Jinping, President of the People's Republic of China, to Russia. The loan carries a 16 year maturity (and a final maturity date of May 2029) and an unknown interest rate. It was secured (collateralized) with a contract for crude oil supplies signed by Rosneft and CNPC in 2009. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower for the development of Vankor field (an oil and gas field in Turukhansk District and Krasnoyarsk Krai within Eastern Siberia) and to facilitate the supply of gas to China. OJSC VTB Bank was the agent and passport bank for the loan.   On July 29, 2013, Rosneft disclosed that the $2 billion loan from CDB had fully disbursed in June 2013.
justification: Loan specifically for oil field development and gas supply, directly supporting fossil fuel infrastructure
evidence: $2 billion oil-backed loan, development of Vankor oil and gas field, gas supply to China

title: Bank of China participates in $14.212 billion syndicated loan to Rosneft for acquisition of 50% stake in TNK-BP
description: On November 22, 2012, PJSC Rosneft Oil Company — Russia’s third largest hydrocarbon producer operating in Russia’s major hydrocarbon regions (including Western Siberia, Volga-Urals and Eastern Siberia) with assets in Ukraine, Belarus, Venezuela, Vietnam and Brazil — acquired 50% stake in TNK-BP from BP for $17.1 billion in cash and 1,360,449,797 Rosneft stock shares (representing a 12.84% ownership stake in Rosneft). To facilitate this acquisition, Rosneft obtained a 5-year loan of $4.1 billion and a 2-year loan of $12.7 billion from a group of international banks, including include Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays Bank, BNP Paribas, BTMU, Citibank, Credit Agricole, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo Banking Group, J.P. Morgan, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Natixis, Nordea Bank, SMBC, Societe Generale and Unicredit Bank.   Then, on March 21, 2013, Rosneft provided BP $12.5 billion in cash and a 19.75% ownership stake in Rosneft in order to acquire the remaining 50% stake in TNK-BP. To facilitate this acquisition, Rosneft signed a $14.212 billion syndicated loan on February 13, 2013 with Bank of China, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays Bank, BNP Paribas, BTMU, Citibank, Credit Agricole, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo Banking Group, J.P. Morgan, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Natixis, Nordea Bank, SMBC, Societe Generale, Unicredit Bank. Bank of China’s monetary contribution to syndicated loan is unknown. The loan carried a 2-year maturity (final maturity date: February 13, 2015) and an interest rate of 1-month LIBOR plus a 1.9% margin. The average 1-month LIBOR rate in February 2013 was 0.20%, so the all-in interest rate has been estimated as 0.20% + 1.90% = 2.1%.  Rosneft announced in December 2013 that it had begun early repayment of the $14.212 billion loan. The loan was repaid in full in December 2014.
staff_comments: 1. For the time being, AidData has estimated the contribution of the Chinese state-owned bank by assuming that the sixteen lenders contributed equal amounts ($888,250,000) to the loan syndicate. 2. Rosneft’s identification number for the loan is 0000813/0796Д. 3. One source (https://www.dropbox.com/s/yghw3skjom1uzbu/results-q1-13.pdf?dl=0) suggests that the face value of the 2-year bridge loan was $11.88 billion and it was bundled with a separate $2,332,000,000 term loan facility. This issue merits further investigation. 4. Rosneft is a Russian state-owned company.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Bank of China participates in $14.212 billion syndicated loan to Rosneft for acquisition of 50% stake in TNK-BP

# Description
On November 22, 2012, PJSC Rosneft Oil Company — Russia’s third largest hydrocarbon producer operating in Russia’s major hydrocarbon regions (including Western Siberia, Volga-Urals and Eastern Siberia) with assets in Ukraine, Belarus, Venezuela, Vietnam and Brazil — acquired 50% stake in TNK-BP from BP for $17.1 billion in cash and 1,360,449,797 Rosneft stock shares (representing a 12.84% ownership stake in Rosneft). To facilitate this acquisition, Rosneft obtained a 5-year loan of $4.1 billion and a 2-year loan of $12.7 billion from a group of international banks, including include Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays Bank, BNP Paribas, BTMU, Citibank, Credit Agricole, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo Banking Group, J.P. Morgan, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Natixis, Nordea Bank, SMBC, Societe Generale and Unicredit Bank.   Then, on March 21, 2013, Rosneft provided BP $12.5 billion in cash and a 19.75% ownership stake in Rosneft in order to acquire the remaining 50% stake in TNK-BP. To facilitate this acquisition, Rosneft signed a $14.212 billion syndicated loan on February 13, 2013 with Bank of China, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Barclays Bank, BNP Paribas, BTMU, Citibank, Credit Agricole, ING Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo Banking Group, J.P. Morgan, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Natixis, Nordea Bank, SMBC, Societe Generale, Unicredit Bank. Bank of China’s monetary contribution to syndicated loan is unknown. The loan carried a 2-year maturity (final maturity date: February 13, 2015) and an interest rate of 1-month LIBOR plus a 1.9% margin. The average 1-month LIBOR rate in February 2013 was 0.20%, so the all-in interest rate has been estimated as 0.20% + 1.90% = 2.1%.  Rosneft announced in December 2013 that it had begun early repayment of the $14.212 billion loan. The loan was repaid in full in December 2014.
justification: Syndicated loan supports acquisition of oil company stakes, directly facilitating fossil fuel operations
evidence: Loan to Rosneft for acquisition of TNK-BP, both major oil companies, with operations in multiple hydrocarbon regions

title: CDB provides $800 million loan for Moscow Multipurpose Complex Construction Project
description: In October 2013, China Development Bank signed an $800 million loan agreement with Vnesheconombank (VEB) for the construction of a multipurpose complex in Moscow. The loan has a maturity of 6 years. The interest rate and grace period of the loan are unknown. The loan agreement was signed at the same time as a CDB loan agreement for the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Plant in Kazakhstan (see Project ID#53544).   The complex is located on the territory of the former "Slava" clocks factory near Moscow's Belorusskiy Vokzal train station. This factory was demolished in November 2008. The Chinese sources indicate that the multifunctional complex involves some type of science and technology park (莫斯科“光荣”科技园区), while Russian sources refer to it as a multifunctional complex for business centers (Административно деловые центры).   The contractor responsible for implementation is MR Group. The Moscow Multifunctional Complex Construction Project appears to be nearing implementation. It has been designed by a British architect named Philip Ball and it has undergone architectural review. However, it is not clear if construction has begun. The complex, which will occupy an area of 479,715 square meters, is scheduled for commissioning in 2015.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the the Slava Technopark Multi-purpose Complex Construction Project. The Russian project title is Жилой комплекс 'Slava' or проекте многофункционального комплекса (МФК) or проекта строительства многофункционального комплекса на территории московского часового завода ОАО «Слава».
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
CDB provides $800 million loan for Moscow Multipurpose Complex Construction Project

# Description
In October 2013, China Development Bank signed an $800 million loan agreement with Vnesheconombank (VEB) for the construction of a multipurpose complex in Moscow. The loan has a maturity of 6 years. The interest rate and grace period of the loan are unknown. The loan agreement was signed at the same time as a CDB loan agreement for the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Plant in Kazakhstan (see Project ID#53544).   The complex is located on the territory of the former "Slava" clocks factory near Moscow's Belorusskiy Vokzal train station. This factory was demolished in November 2008. The Chinese sources indicate that the multifunctional complex involves some type of science and technology park (莫斯科“光荣”科技园区), while Russian sources refer to it as a multifunctional complex for business centers (Административно деловые центры).   The contractor responsible for implementation is MR Group. The Moscow Multifunctional Complex Construction Project appears to be nearing implementation. It has been designed by a British architect named Philip Ball and it has undergone architectural review. However, it is not clear if construction has begun. justification: Project involves construction of a multipurpose complex with mixed-use functions including business centers and potential science/technology components, but lacks clear environmental or energy transition focus
evidence: Multipurpose complex construction, mixed-use development (business centers and potential science/technology park), no specific energy or environmental components mentioned
